The strength of the course was that it covered quite a bit of material that I needed to know.  The weakness of the course is that it was incredibly focused on the math of quantum mechanics, as opposed to gaining an intuitive understanding of what's really going on.

Professor Read taught this course at a very high level, way beyond the textbook we use. You can learn a lot if you are familiar with the material. However, most of the time, students in his class just don't know what he is talking about since he basically assumed that you already knew the textbook well.

Strengths:
The homework problems Prof Read came up with were very interesting. Covered fair amount of material for Grad QM 2 class. Lectures were very rigorous, and questions were answered well.

Weaknesses: 
Some sakurai problems are unnecessarily long, not sure why we did them. A few lectures had a lot of hard-to-follow math, which did not seem useful. Homework grading was somewhat slow, which was annoying when reviewing for the midterm/final. Hard parts of the class (i.e. scattering) were shoved towards the end, which made things more difficult.
The materials have much emphasis on the maths than on the intuitions.
Lectures were very methodical. The course could be improved by assigning shorter, more frequent homework assignments, to keep pace with the lectures.
More time should spent on topics covered at the end of the course.  The main strength of the course is that Nick Read either writes good problems, or picks good problems from Sakurai.

Gives a solid grounding in the mathematics of these topics in Quantum Mechanics. I personally got a bit lost in the math at times, and would perhaps have preferred if in class, it could be made more transparent where the mathematics is heading before we start.
